title: 114_hr4293
content: The "Affordable Retirement Advice Protection Act" aims to hold advisors accountable for providing impermissible advice or breaching the best interest standard for investment advice under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is being amended to define investment advice as recommendations related to acquiring, holding, disposing, or exchanging plan assets, including advice on taking distributions or investing plan funds. The amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 defines investment advice as recommendations on managing plan assets, including advice on distributions and retaining advisors who receive compensation for providing such advice. The advice must be accompanied by an acknowledgment of compliance with section 404 or a mutual agreement. The amendment to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 defines investment advice as recommendations on managing plan assets, including advice on distributions and retaining advisors who receive compensation for providing such advice. Any disclaimer of a mutual agreement, arrangement, or understanding should state that the information is not individualized and should not be relied upon for investment decisions. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 defines investment advice as recommendations on managing plan assets. Any disclaimer of a mutual agreement should clearly state that the information is not individualized and should not be relied upon for investment decisions. The disclaimer must be in writing, communicated clearly, and prominently displayed. Information provided in a marketing or sales capacity must also include the disclaimer. The person is not providing investment advice or acting under the best interest standard. They may provide information as a counterparty or service provider to a plan, but only if the plan is represented by an independent plan fiduciary in connection with the transaction. The independent plan fiduciary must confirm in writing that they are aware of the person's financial interest in the transaction and that the person is not providing investment advice or acting as a fiduciary to the plan. The person providing the information must be an employee of a sponsoring employer or employee organization and provide the information to the plan for no fee. The person providing information to the plan must disclose in writing that they are not providing investment advice as a fiduciary. The information consists of making securities available through a platform for plan fiduciaries to select investment alternatives for plan participants. The information provided to the plan includes identifying investment alternatives based on specified criteria and providing financial data and comparisons with benchmarks. This information may consist solely of valuation information or information described in Department of Labor Interpretive Bulletin 96-1. Interpretive Bulletin 96-1 (29 C.F.R. 2509.96-1, as in effect on January 1, 2015) covers education provided to plan participants or beneficiaries on factors to consider when deciding on plan distributions or rollovers. Examples of distribution alternatives must be accompanied by relevant information. The curr_chunk discusses exemptions related to investment advice under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. It outlines conditions for transactions involving investment advice and reasonable compensation. The curr_chunk outlines conditions for investment advice transactions, including the requirement for reasonable compensation and disclosure of limited investment options. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need for clear disclosure of variable compensation in investment advice transactions. The curr_chunk highlights the requirement for transparent disclosure of variable compensation in investment advice transactions, including details on fees and compensation payable to the advisor. The curr_chunk emphasizes the need for disclosing compensation details in investment advice transactions, including specific amounts payable to the advisor upon request. The curr_chunk clarifies that errors or omissions in disclosing compensation details in investment advice transactions will not invalidate a recommendation if corrected within 30 days. Additionally, any required notices related to disclosure do not replace other necessary notices. The Department of Labor is prohibited from amending rules or administrative positions under section 3(21) of ERISA, including Interpretive Bulletin 96-1 and Advisory Opinion 2005-23A, that were promulgated before but not effective on January 1, 2015. The Department of Labor is prohibited from amending rules or administrative positions under ERISA section 3(21) before January 1, 2015. Any amendments made by this Act will take effect 61 days after enactment, except if a bill is passed within 60 days approving specific rules or positions. The amendments made by this Act regarding positions under ERISA section 3(21) that are not in effect on January 1, 2015, will not take effect. Grandfathered transactions and services prior to the effective date of the amendments will not be affected. Guidance can be issued to implement the amendments as needed. A plan or fiduciary will be considered compliant with new amendments if they follow a reasonable good faith interpretation of the regulations or guidance issued to implement the amendments.
